title: Please help me choose a typeface!
content:
I need to design a t-shirt with two words on it and am having trouble finding an appropriate typeface. The t-shirts are aimed primarily at 30-/40-somethings and are not ’comedy’ but will probably raise a wry smile from those who get the reference, which is to a pop song from the eighties.

I can’t reveal the text yet (sorry), but it’s along the lines of “Like a Yo-Yo” - i.e. lyrics from part of a song. If there is to be a whiff of retro about it, then it should be subtle.

I would be very grateful for your suggestions!  
Thank you,  
Kate

 [‹ Check mark symbol?](http://web.archive.org/web/20080121165316/http:/www.typophile.com/node/41082 "Go to previous forum topic") [mixed-type logotype ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080121165316/http:/www.typophile.com/node/40985 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Kate_K

comments.content:
The original <cite>CHOOSE LIFE</cite> T-shirts designed by Katharine Hamnett were set in [Folio Bold Condensed](http://web.archive.org/web/20080121165316/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/folio/bold-condensed/) (or something similar).

Folio is generic-looking enough that it doesn’t look overtly “retro” by any means, but people who get the reference will recognize the face from the original T-shirt, consciously or otherwise.

It’s hard not to think of 80s culture without [Neville Brody](http://web.archive.org/web/20080121165316/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/Neville%252BBrody) and ’The Face’ magazine coming to mind. How about his typeface [Insignia](http://web.archive.org/web/20080121165316/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/Insignia)? It’s nice in all caps.
Thank you, these are both great!
